title: Add gas price query and subscription to GraphQL API
description:
DESIGN: Gas Price Support

SCHEMA CHANGES:
- New Query: gasPrice: GasPriceResult!
- New Subscription: gasPriceUpdated: GasPrice!
- Types: GasPrice (baseFee, priorityFee, updatedAt), GasPriceResult union

IMPLEMENTATION:
- Store gas price in-memory only (no database persistence)
- Indexer: Extract baseFeePerGas from block headers, cache in-memory
- Indexer: Periodically fetch priorityFee from RPC
- Indexer: Broadcast GasPriceUpdated events when values change
- API Query: Read from in-memory cache, return QueryFailedError if not initialized
- API Subscription: Emit current value as snapshot, stream subsequent updates
- On restart: Gas price resets, clients get fresh data

NO DATABASE CHANGES - data is too volatile to persist

title: native and hopr balance support
description:
The GraphQL API allows querying of hopr and native balances. This only makes sense to support for HOPR safes, HOPR node EOA accounts and the channels contract.
Even then the amount of chain logs which would have to be stored is a lot. Thus blokli uses the following approach. 
During initial sync transfer logs (ERC20) and transfer transactions (native) are completely ignored. Once synched the indexer also subscribes to these events. 
Internally blokli keeps an in-memory set of addresses which combines all known HOPR safe addresses, EOA addresses and the channels contract address. 
Once an ERC20 transfer event is being handled, it will check against this set of addresses. 
If the address is known, the balance will be fetched from chain via the RPC (sync operation) and the result stored in the in-memory data structure. If a balance is fetched via the GraphQL API it will try to read the balance from the data structure. If the key is not present, an error will be returned. If the key (address) is present and no balance is known yet, it will be fetched directly from the RPC (sync operation), stored in the data structure and returned to the API caller. If the balance is known, it will be returned directly.
A similar approach is taken for native transfers. For these the indexer
subscribes to new blocks and checks all transactions in a new block for known
addresses. If a known address is found, the native balance is fetched from chain
via the RPC (sync operation) and the result stored in the in-memory data
structure. The GraphQL API behaves the same way as for ERC20 balances.
